comment.author: 21222453@N05
comment._content:
I do not think the building on the right is the Kulm Hotel, unless it's one that has since been taken down.  Notice that it sits further away, so "behind" the tower in distance from the tower.  The links that show modern day St. Moritz have the hotel buildings closer, or "in front" of the tower.  Even if the image is flipped, it wouldn't account for that discrepency.  I do however agree that the mountains in the BG look the same, just reversed and the tower matches.

Also was wondering....seems in the forefront is an ice skating area.  One person looks like there is a reflection there and it looks like the snow is pushed back and there is a path from the "road" to the ice.  Does St. Mortiz fit this?  Just curious.  Never been there so just analyzing it:)  Seems to me that the leaning tower is closer to the ice than what the lake in St. Moritz is currently.

comment.author: 77488044@N00
comment._content: Clearly St. Moritz, but reversed, as others have already said. This image is almost the same as photo 11 on the official St. Moritz page at www.stmoritz.ch/en/history-en/birthplace-of-alpine-winter...

comment.author: 21222453@N05
comment._content: Photo #13 has the building as well that is on the right of the above photo.  A portion of the building is in photo 11 but not all of it.  And these historical photos shown on the website listed in Steven Bufton's comment show the ice rinks as well that I questioned earlier.  Though, based on #13's date, I would say the photo above is earlier than 1872 since #13's photo has more buildings and they are slightly different as in more was added.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Comparison with the image by Sacred Destinations (photochrom flipped, SD's image elongated to account for perspective distortion): Note that the nave of the church (Sankt Mauritius) was torn down in 1890, so the original picture must be older than that.

comment.author: 69879869@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called The Astonishing Power of Flickr, which was created to celebrate discoveries made about photographs posted on Flickr, and we'd love to have this added to the group! Another fascinating debate!

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: According to this very excellent book*, the first series of photochroms by the Photochrom AG Zürich (what later turned into Photoglob Zürich) started with the serial number 1001 in 1889. Since this image is numbered 1011, it should be among the very first photochroms ever issued. *No worries about the title, the book is in French, German and English.
